On Mon, 2003-09-22 at 13:12, Vincent Massol wrote:
> Hi Jason,
> 
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jacaetevha@...]
> > Sent: 22 September 2003 18:34
> > To: JUnit
> > Subject: Re: [junit] Can I test web application using JUnit?
> > 
> > On Mon, 2003-09-22 at 05:35, Narendra S wrote:
> > > If u are interested in testing the servlets try Cactus
> > > http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/index.html
> > > ----- Original Message -----
> > 
> > I would suggest qualifying that statement.  I have been a part of 5
> > large projects now that have all used the Servlet technology.  Not a
> > single one of those projects needed the overhead of Cactus.  In fact,
> I
> > am not sure what the benefit of it is.  (That is not a derogatory
> > remark.)  Can you sum up the things that Cactus brings to the table
> over
> > JUnit+HTTPUnit or JUnit+HTMLUnit?
> 
> I have my ideas, but I'd like to know too why people are using Cactus
> :-) (there must be a few using it I guess). What do they find
> interesting? Why don't they use the solution you mention (the real
> solution is JUnit+MockObjects/Stubs+HTTPUnit though if you want to
> compare it to Cactus)?

Is that always true?  Are you assuming that people are using Cactus only
for J2EE unit testing wherein they would need a container?

> Is it simply by lack of knowledge? Is it because
> Cactus is better "marketed" than other solutions?

Marketing?  Java technologies?  Never!  ;)  (GO!! Smalltalk!)

=jason
